Tools of the Trade â€¢ Jon Reades & Fulvio Lopane


Probably the best â€˜lay personâ€™sâ€™ explanation of how LLMs work/fall apart youâ€™ll ever read.And this one was trained on scientific articles!Part art, part activism, part tech!

title: Group Working
text:
Many Modelsâ€¦

Artist Collectives â€” shared responsibilities for ideas and outputs; a lot of freedom and fuzziness in roles, but propensity for struggles over direction and power.
Theatre â€” every member has a specific role; there is freedom within the role and clear lines of responsibility for delivery, but can blow up spectacularly.
Co-Creation â€” emphasis on participation and recognition of diverse strengths; problem- and communication-focused; lots of effort and uncertainty, but results can be much more meaningful and durable.
â€¦


The arts world is particularly innovative when it comes to project work because teams are always being formed and reformed around individual outputs (a play, an artistic collaboration, a theatre production)â€¦
Fields such as consultancy and software development have their own norms, but they are for the most part less experimental in their structure.
However, the point is that there is no one-size-fits-all pattern for a successful piece of group work.

title: Group Working
text:
Challenges

We make superficial assessments of the flaws/strengths of others.
We make a range of assumptions about the motivations of others.
We make a range of assumptions about the situations of others.
We respond differently to stimuli and stresses.
We have a hard time talking about any of this.


These are just some of the challenges to setting up your group.
In particular, when we meet a new group, itâ€™s often easy to be impressed by someone who is self-confident and well-spoken: they must know what theyâ€™re doing! Group dynamics can be like a popularity contest in which the person who is easy-going or â€˜funâ€™ is making a wonderful contribution, while the one who asks difficult questions is â€˜not constructiveâ€™ and â€˜not contributingâ€™. Someone who is â€˜quietâ€™ doesnâ€™t seem to have much to sayâ€¦

title: Group Working
text:
Identifying Your Strengths


Dominance

Results-oriented
Innovative
Competitive
Direct

Influence

People-oriented
Enthusiastic
Optimistic
Creative


Steadiness

Sincere
Dependable
Patient
Modest

Conscientiousness

Accurate
Cautious
Precise
Analytical



Here is one way of moving beyond the stereotype that the person doing the talking is also doing the thinking. The DISC model is apparently connected back to Wonder Woman by her creator W.M Marston. Like Wonder Woman, this is a model that reflects its cultural context: it was created for American teams and if you arenâ€™t American then you might find that these four personality types donâ€™t â€˜fitâ€™ very well. But itâ€™s still a good place to start talking about preferences, behaviours, and the way they impact others.

title: Group Working
section: Too Much of a Good Thing
text:
Too Much of a Good Thing


Dominance

Fails to involve others
Impatient
Offensive

Influence

Too social
Easily distracted
Overly optimistic


Steadiness

Indirect
Avoids conflict
Delays difficult decisions

Conscientiousness

Perfectionist
Avoids unsystematic people
Delays decisions over risks



Anything that is a strength in one context can become a weakness in another.
For instance, a dominant personality might assume that the fact no one else is objecting means that there is support for their proposal; however, it could just be that the rest of the group wants to avoid conflict even though they think there are significant risks.
Or someone who is motivated by the social component might spend so long bringing people together to talk about directions (and constantly adding new ideas to the mix) that very little progress is made on the actual project!

title: Group Working
text:
Consequences1

title: Group Working
text:
Every Good Plan1â€¦





Source: Zentao

title: Group Working
text:
Nothing Ever Goes to Plan
From relational to practicalâ€¦

Agile principles1: iterative delivery of successful projects focussed on individuals and interactions; working software, customer collaboration; and responding to change.
Scrum methodology2: organised around stand ups, sprints, sprint review, and retrospectives.
Kanban methodology: use of â€˜sticky notesâ€™ in columns to organise and prioritise visually.
XP methdology: one person writes/codes while a partner researches/solves/feeds back.


One challenge that teams face in the world of software is failure due to complexity and change.
You may have seen â€˜Waterfall chartsâ€™ of the sort produced by project management software where one task cascades into the next until the project is delivered at the end. This is recipe for failure. The Mythical Man Month comprehensively debunked this approach in 1975.
The general conclusion was that â€œAdding more people to a project that is late makes it later.â€ The reason this happens is that you cannot break a complex task into discrete parts, send someone away to work on it in isolation, and then have them report back at the end with a finished product. I have seen this happen in previous yearsâ€™ group work too: one person did a lit review while someone else was writing code but they didnâ€™t line up at the end!
I saw this in graphic design too: a client writes a brief for exactly what they want. You deliver something exactly like what they asked for. And they say thatâ€™s not what they meant.
The Agile philosophy emerged in response to these kinds of failures, with the approach that the product should be finished as quickly as possible, but as provisionally as possible. So you always have a working application, even if it only does a fraction of what you intend for it to do in the long run.
This has been elevated by companies like Facebook to slogans along the lines of â€˜Fail Fastâ€™, but the point is to recognise as quickly as possible when something isnâ€™t working or isnâ€™t headed in the direction you planned.
For the group work at the heart of this module, the point of the iterative process that begins in Week 6 is to help you develop competency in using the tools required to make your submission, to start you thinking along the lines that are required for the more complex questions, and to tease out points of failure in the groupâ€™s ability to work together long before you are under the tight deadline at the end of term!

Source: SimpleLearnSource: Northeastern University

title: Transformation
text:
What is it?
Data transformation just means changing the raw data in some way to make it more tractable for analysis.
For example:

Centering the mean on zero is an obvious example.
But we can also do quite complicated things (with caution!) in order to get a distribution that we can work with using statistical tests that have certain expectations about the data weâ€™re feeding them.


So, even though we add or subtract, multiply or divide, square or log the data, because we are doing the same thing to every observation the underlying relationships between the data are â€˜unchangedâ€™.

title: Transformation
text:
Transformation in 1D


\[
x-\bar{x}
\]



Input
Output




12
-2


13
-1


14
0


15
+1


16
+2





How is this any different?

title: Transformation
text:
Soâ€¦

Transformations are mathematical operations applied to every observation in a data set that preserve some of the relationships between them.

title: Transformation
text:
For Example
If we subtract the mean from everyoneâ€™s height then we can immediately tell if someone is taller or shorter than we would expect.
If we subtract the mean from everyoneâ€™s income then we cannot immediately tell if someone is earning more or less that we would expect.
So what is a useful transformation in one context, may not be in another!

title: Transformation
text:
Fleshing This Out
Question: How can you tell if you did better than everyone else on the Quiz or on the Final Report?

Answer: Just subtracting the mean is not enough because the distributions are not the same. For that we also need to standardise the data in some way.
\[
z = \dfrac{x-\bar{x}}{\sigma}
\]
Divide through by the distribution!

title: Transformation
text:
Z-Score Standardisation
\[
\dfrac{x-\bar{x}}{\sigma}
\]
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
scaler = StandardScaler()
scaler.fit(x)
print(scaler.mean_)
scaler.transform(x)

The important thing to note is that if transform data that has not been fit and you get values outside the range used for fitting then you can no longer assume a standard normal.

title: Transformation
text:
Interquartile Standardisation
\[
\dfrac{x_{i}-x_{Q2}}{x_{Q3}-x_{Q1}}
\]
from sklearn.preprocessing import RobustScaler
trf = RobustScaler(
        quantile_range=(25.0,75.0)).fit(x)
trf.transform(x)

title: Transformation
text:
Interdecile Standardisation
\[
\dfrac{x_{i}-x_{50^{th}}}{x_{90^{th}}-x_{10^{th}}}
\]
print("You've got this...")

Why standardise:

We understand the properties of normal-ish distributions, and can simulate them easily.
More â€˜powerâ€™ in the statistical tools available.
Many analyses assume that â€˜errorâ€™ is random and symmetric (homoscedastic, not skewed).

title: Transformation
text:
Group Standardisation
\[
x'_{a,i} = \dfrac{x_{ai}}{\sum_{g} r_{N,g} P_{a,g}}
\]

Details:

\(x_{a,i}\) = Value of attribute i in area a.
\(P_{a,g}\) = Population of group g in area a.
\(r_{N,g}\) = National ratio N of group g
\(\sum\) = Sum for all groups.
\(x'_{a,i}\) = Standardised value of i in area a.

title: Transformation
text:
Proportional Normalisation
\[
\dfrac{x_{i}}{\sum{x}_{i=1}^{n}}
\]
import numpy as np
x/np.sum(x)

Numpy has a fair few options for implementing this, but note that log means natural log, not log10!

title: Transformation
text:
Range Normalisation
\[
\dfrac{x_{i}-x_{min}}{x_{max}-x_{min}}
\]
from sklearn.preprocessing import MinMaxScaler
scaler = MinMaxScaler()
scaler.fit(x)
print(scaler.data_max_)
scaler.transform(x)

Normalisation helps in several ways:

Scaling is important for comparability
Clustering is particularly sensitive to scale

title: Transformation
text:
Log Transformation
Recall: logs are the inverse of exponentiation!

So if \(10^{3} = 1,000\) then \(log_{10}(1,000) = 3\).
And if \(10^{0} = 1\) then \(log_{10}(1) = 0\)

import numpy as np
xhat = np.log(x)


Why is this so common? Esp. in social sciences?


Note that numpy uses the natural log in base \(e\).

title: Transformation
text:
Why Log Transform?
Letâ€™s assume that \(x = \{10, 100, 1000, 10000\}\), consider what happens if:

The formula for the mean is \(\frac{\sum{x}}{n}\).
The formula for variance is \(\frac{(x-\bar{x})^{2}}{n}\).

The Natural Log (\(e\)) has certain advantages over other logs and should probably be your default choice for log transformations.

title: Transformation
text:
Other Transformsâ€¦

Quantile (maps the PDF of each feature to a uniform distribution)
Square Root (often with count data)
Arcsine/Angular (with percentages, proportions, text)
Rank (with care on extreme distributions)
Box-Cox and Yeo-Johnson (arbitrary power transformations)



To report measures of central tendency itâ€™s usually helpful to convert back to the original units.
The more extreme the transformation the less meaningful measures of dispersion.
Correlation can be significantly affected in either direction.
Count data can be tricky because you should not have negative values (especially \(-\infty\)).

title: Transformation
text:
When Transforms Donâ€™t Help
Arbitrarily transforming data isnâ€™t a panacea. â€˜Robustâ€™ tests can be another approach when all else fails and two common approaches are:

Trimming: cutting off, say, the top and bottom 5% of scores would start to remove skew and offer a more useful view of the central tendency of the data.
Bootstrapping: taking many sub-samples (usually of \(n-1\) data points or similar) we can build a picture of how certain metrics vary.

title: Transformation
text:
One Last Note

The term normalization is used in many contexts, with distinct, but related, meanings. Basically, normalizing means transforming so as to render normal. When data are seen as vectors, normalizing means transforming the vector so that it has unit norm. When data are though of as random variables, normalizing means transforming to normal distribution. When the data are hypothesized to be normal, normalizing means transforming to unit variance.

Source: Stack Exchange

title: Grouping Data
text:
Useful, But Limited?



Method
Achieves




count()
Total number of items


first(), last()
First and last item


mean(), median()
Mean and median


min(), max()
Minimum and maximum


std(), var()
Standard deviation and variance


mad()
Mean absolute deviation


prod()
Product of all items


sum()
Sum of all items




Here are a bunch of pandas functions that have to do with aggregating data in some way. Some of these youâ€™ll have seen before, some you may not. However, up to this point if you wanted to to know the median price of each type of Airbnb listing, or the sum of each type of vehicle sold, youâ€™d have had to select out one listing type or vehicle type, call median or sum, and then remember the result. Letâ€™s change that.

title: Grouping Data
text:
Grouping Operations
In Pandas these follow a split / apply / combine approach:


Note that, for simplicity, Iâ€™ve abbreviate the Local Authority names since this is just a simplified example: TH (Tower Hamlets), HAK (Hackney), W (Westminster).

title: Grouping Data
text:
In Practice
grouped_df = df.groupby(<fields>).<function>
For instance, if we had a Local Authority (LA) field:
grouped_df = df.groupby('LA').sum()
Using apply the function could be anything:
def norm_by_data(x): # x is a column from the grouped df
    x['d1'] /= x['d2'].sum() 
    return x

df.groupby('LA').apply(norm_by_data)

title: Grouping Data
text:
Grouping by Arbitrary Mappings
mapping = {'HAK':'Inner', 'TH':'Outer', 'W':'Inner'}
df.set_index('LA', inplace=True)
df.groupby(mapping).sum()

title: Grouping Data
text:
Pivot Tables
A â€˜special caseâ€™ of Group By features:

Commonly-used in business to summarise data for reporting.
Grouping (summarisation) happens along both axes (Group By operates only on one).
pandas.cut(<series>, <bins>) can be a useful feature here since it chops a continuous feature into bins suitable for grouping.

title: Grouping Data
text:
In Practice
age = pd.cut(titanic['age'], [0, 18, 80])
titanic.pivot_table('survived', ['sex', age], 'class')

title: Grouping Data
text:
Deriving Measures of Diversity

One of the benefits of grouping is that it enables us to derive measures of density and diversity; here are just a fewâ€¦ Location Quotient (LQ), Herfindah-Hirschman Index (HHI), Shanon Entropy.


I like easy measures.

title: Grouping Data
text:
Location Quotient
The LQ for industry i in zone z is the share of employment for i in z divided by the share of employment of i in the entire region R. \[
LQ_{zi} = \dfrac{Emp_{zi}/Emp_{z}}{Emp_{Ri}/Emp_{R}}
\]



Â 
High Local Share
Low Local Share




High Regional Share
\[\approx 1\]
\[< 1\]


Low Regional Share
\[> 1\]
\[\approx 1\]




In other words, this is a type of standardisation that enables to compare the concentration of Investment Bankers with the concentration of Accountants, even if there are many more Accountants than Bankers! But this can also apply to the share of flats to whole-property lettings just as easily.
Note that this is influenced by small sample sizes (e.g.Â the number of Fijians in Britain).

title: Grouping Data
text:
Herfindahl-Hirschman index
The HHI for an industry i is the sum of squared market shares for each company in that industry: \[
H = \sum_{i=1}^{N} s_{i}^{2}
\]







Concentration Level
HHI




Monopolistic: one firm accounts for 100% of the market
\[1.0\]


Oligopolistic: top five firms account for 60% of the market
\[\approx 0.8\]


Competitive: anything else?
\[< 0.5\]?




If \(s_{i} = 1\) then \(s_{i}^{2} = 1\), while if \(s_{i} = 0.5\) then \(s_{i}^{2} = 0.25\) and \(s_{i} = 0.1\) then \(s_{i}^{2} = 0.01\).
This can be translated to compare, for instance, local and regional neighbourhood diversity: some cities are ethnically diverse in aggregate but highly segregated at the local level.
Note that this is influenced by the number of â€˜firmsâ€™ (or ethnicities orâ€¦).

title: Grouping Data
text:
Shannon Entropy
Shannon Entropy is an information-theoretic measure: \[
H(X) = - \sum_{i=1}^{n} P(x_{i}) log P(x_{i})
\]

I often think of this as â€˜surpriseâ€™: a high entropy measure means that itâ€™s hard to predict what will happen next. So randomness has high entropy. By extension, high concentration has low entropy (even if the result is surprising on the level of intuition: I wasnâ€™t expecting to see that) because I can predict a 6 on the next roll of the dice fairly easy if all of my previous rolls were 6s.

title: Clustering
text:
Spot the Difference


Classification

Allocates n samples to k groups
Works for different values of k
Different algorithms (A) present different views of group relationships
Poor choices of A and k lead to weak understanding of data
Typically works best in 1â€“2 dimensions


Clustering

Allocates n samples to k groups
Works for different values of k
Different algorithms A present different views of group relationships
Poor choices of A and k lead to weak understanding of data
Typically works best in < 9 dimensions



Clustering algorithms can suffer from the â€˜curse of dimensionalityâ€™ such that high-dimensional spaces cluster poorly without either dimensionality reduction or the use of specialist algorithms such as Spherical k-Means.

Intimately Linked to Rise of The State

Geodemographics only possible in context of a State â€“ without a Census it simply wouldnâ€™t workâ€¦ until now?
Clearly tied to social and economic â€˜controlâ€™ and intervention: regeneration, poverty & exclusion, crime, etc.
Presumes that areas are the relevant unit of analysis; in geodemographics these are usually called neighbourhoodsâ€¦ which should ring a few bells.
In practice, we are in the realm of â€˜homophilyâ€™, a.k.a. Toblerâ€™s First Law of Geography

title: Clustering
text:
Where is it used?
Anything involving grouping individuals, households, or areas into larger â€˜groupsâ€™â€¦

Strategic marketing (above the line, targeted, etc.)
Retail analysis (store location, demand modelling, etc.)
Public sector planning (resource allocation, service development, etc.)

Could see it as a subset of customer segmentation.

text:
Problem Domains




Continuous
Categorical




Supervised

Unsupervised
Dimensionality Reduction
Clustering





In classification we â€˜knowâ€™ the answer (we test against labels).
In clustering we donâ€™t â€˜knowâ€™ the answer (we look for clusters).

title: Clustering
text:
Measuring â€˜Fitâ€™

Usually working towards an â€˜objective criterionâ€™ for qualityâ€¦ these are known as cohesion and separation measures.

title: Clustering
text:
How Your Data Looksâ€¦
Clustering is one area where standardisation (and, frequently, normalisation) are essential:

You donâ€™t (normally) want scale in any one dimension to matter more than scale in another.
You donâ€™t want differences between values in one dimension to matter more than differences in another.
You donâ€™t want skew in one dimension to matter more than skew in another.

You also want uncorrelated variablesâ€¦ why?

title: Clustering
text:
First Steps
You will normally want a continuous variableâ€¦ so these types of data are especially problematic:

Dummies / One-Hot Encoded
Categorical / Ordinal
Possible solutions: k-modes, CCA, etc.

Typically about trade-offs between:



Accuracy
Generalisation

title: Clustering
text:
Trade-Offs
Need to balance:

Ability to cluster at speed.
Ability to replicate results.
Ability to cope with fuzzy/indeterminate boundaries.
Ability to cope with curse of dimensionality.
Underlying representation of group membershipâ€¦

title: Clustering
text:
Visualising the Trade-Offs



Notice the limitations to k-means: it may be fast but itâ€™s got problems if your data is non-linear/non-Gaussian.
And this doesnâ€™t even include options like HDBSCAN, HAC/Hierarchical Clustering, and many more!


Details on scikit-learn.org.

title: Computers in Urban Studies
text:
3 Waves?


â€œA computer in every institutionâ€
â€œA computer in every officeâ€
â€œA computer in every thingâ€



Wave 1

Roughly the 1950sâ€“70s
Computers as â€˜super-humanâ€™ calculators for data
Data + models as theory-testing tool

Retrospectively: the 1st quantitative revolution. But can see this as incorrect and focus on the theoretical aspect.
Wave 2

Roughly the 1980sâ€“2000s
Computers as tools for thinking about spatial relationships
Explicit modelling of local spatial effects

Retrospectively: the GIS revolution. But I personally see this as incorrect because GIS is Wave 1.
Shift from computers as processors of data to integrated, pervasive systems that spew out data on everything.
Wave 3

Roughly the mid-2000sâ€“?
Computers as tools for generating data (pace ABM researchers)
Geodata being continuously produced as byproduct of other activities
Shift from researching attributes to behaviours (pace HÃ¤gerstrand)

Retrospectively: the big data revolution or 2nd quantitative revolution.

title: Computers in Urban Studies
text:
All Waves Still Going!
Wave 1: Computers help me do it faster

GIS is â€˜justâ€™ the industrial revolution impacting cartography.

Wave 2: Computers help me to think

Geocomputation & local stats are qualitatively & meaningfully different.

Wave 3: Computers help me to learn

Not â€˜justâ€™ about the â€˜bignessâ€™ of data, though that is important.


Wave 2 is about implementing ideas such as recursion and iteration â€“ these could, in theory, have been tackled in Wave 1, but in practice thatâ€™s not what people were doing.
Wave 3 is about more explicitly allowing computers to learn about data so that we can extract insight from these models â€“ these could also, in theory, have been tackled in Wave 2 but in practice thatâ€™s not what people were doing.
Iâ€™m not totally happy about my description of Wave 3 and will try to dig into this in a little more detail but suggestions welcome!

title: Computers in Urban Studies
text:
Anticipated by HÃ¤gerstrand (1967)

I think that the computer can do three different and useful things for us. The first and simplest operation isâ€¦ descriptive mapping the secondâ€¦ is the analytical one The third kind of service isâ€¦ to run process models by which we might try to reproduce observed or create hypothetical chains of events of a geographical nature.
T. HÃ¤gerstrand (1967), â€˜The Computer and the Geographerâ€™, TiBG

title: Computers in Urban Studies
text:
But Persistent Critiques

There is a clear disparity between the sophisticated theoretical and methodological framework which we are using and our ability to say anything really meaningful about events as they unfold around us. There are too many anomaliesâ€¦ There is an ecological problem, an urban problemâ€¦ and yet we seem incapable of saying anything of any depth or profundity about any of them. When we do say something it appears trite and rather ludicrous.
Harvey (1972, p.6)

I think there are several distinguishing features that I encounter in day-to-day (geography) work:

Data-driven methods development & deployment
Explicit tuning/meta-parameterisation
Explicit feature optimisation/engineering
Explicit training/testing from â€˜one shotâ€™ data
â€˜Black boxesâ€™ feature prominently & â€˜online learningâ€™ emerging quickly

Data science as process and pipeline, not just input to research.

title: Python, the Basics
text:
Variables Have Typesâ€¦



Name
Value
Type




msg
â€˜Hello worldâ€™
type(msg)==str


answer
42
type(answer)==int


pi
3.14159
type(pi)==float


c
complex(5,2)
type(c)==complex


correct
True
type(correct)==bool




As weâ€™ll see in Week 4, everything is also an object.

title: Python, the Basics
section: â€¦ But We Can Change That
text:
â€¦ But We Can Change That
Message starts as a string:
msg = '42'
type(msg) # str
But we can change it to an integer like this:
msg = int(msg)
type(msg) # change to int
And back to a string:
msg = str(msg)
type(msg) # back to str
And notice:
print(str(int('42'))) # string from int from string

That last line of code is intended to start familiarising you with Python syntax: programmers rarely do one operation per line of code if they can do more than one, so youâ€™ll often see nested parentheses like this and you need to learn how to read this kind of code starting from the inner-most parentheses (the int()) and working outwards from there to str() and finally print().

title: Python, the Basics
text:
â€¦And They Are All Objects
One to remember for the session on objects and classes:
isinstance(msg,object)     # True
isinstance(answer,object)  # True
isinstance(pi,object)      # True
isinstance(c,object)       #Â True
isinstance(correct,object) # True

Like str(), int(), and print(), you see here another command â€”Â or â€˜functionâ€™ in Python terminology â€” called ininstance. An â€˜instanceâ€™ of something is just a way of asking â€˜is it a type ofâ€™: so the first line asks if string msg is a kind of object, and the answer to that is: True. But itâ€™s the same for answer (an integer), pi (a floating point number), and so on. They are all a kind of object, and weâ€™ll see why that is a useful answer in a few weeksâ€™ time.

title: Python, the Basics
text:
Variables Have Namesâ€¦
Rules for variable names:

They cannot start with a number: item3 is valid, 3items is not.
White space and symbols are not allowed, but _ is allowed: my_variable is valid, my-variable, my$variable, and my variable are not.
Case matters: myVar is different from both myvar and MYVAR
Be consistent: my_var is more â€˜Pythonicâ€™, though myVar is also widely used; but donâ€™t mix these!
Variable names should be long enough to be clear but not so long as to be impractical: bldg_height vs.Â bh vs.Â max_building_height_at_eaves.

title: Python, the Basics
section: â€¦But Not All Words Are Allowed
text:
â€¦But Not All Words Are Allowed
Do not try to use any of these as variable names. Python may not complain, but strange things will happen when you run your code.



and
del
from
not
while


as
elif
global
or

pass

break

print



class
exec

finally

text:

Letâ€™s start with x=10 and y=5â€¦

Input

5

2.0

2

pow(x,y) or x**y
100000

title: Python, the Basics
text:
Strings Are Different
When you do things with strings the answers can look a little different. Letâ€™s start with x="Hello" and y="You" and z=2â€¦



Operator
Input
Result




Sum
x + y
'HelloYou'


Difference
x - y
TypeError


Product
x * z
HelloHello


Equality
x==y
False

title: Python, the Basics
text:
Using Strings to Output Information
Python has no fewer than three ways output information:

string concatenation using +;
string formatting using <str>.format(<variables>); and
f-strings using f"{variable_1} some text {variable_n}".

There are pros and cons to each:
x = 24
y = 'Something'
print("The value of " + y + " is " + str(x))
print("The value of {0} is {1}".format(y, x))
print(f"The value of {y} is {x}")

Obviously, a really common requirement that programmers have is â€˜output a nicely formatted string containing information about the variables in my programâ€™.
I rather like f-strings because they can actually contain any code you like (you could, for instance, write `fâ€The square root of {y} is {x**(1/2)}â€ and it would work. However, concatenation is the easiest to learn.

title: Python, the Basics
text:
Operators Assemble!
Always pay attention to precedence:
x, y = 10, 5
x + y * 2         # == 20
(x + y) * 2       # == 30
x + y * 2 / 3     # == 13.3333333333334
x + y * (2/3)     # == 13.3333333333332
(x + y) * (2/3)   # == 10.0
And hereâ€™s a subtle one:
(x * y) ** 2/3    # == 833.333333333334
(x * y) ** (2/3)  # == 13.5720880829745
The full list is here.

If youâ€™re a little rusty on exponents, that last example is the cube root of (x*y)**2. But the key point is that formatting is not what matters here, itâ€™s operator precedence: one has parentheses, the other does not, so they are evaluated differently. To make the first one more clear we might use (x * y)**2 / 3 or even ((x*y)**2)/3.
Also notice that with the two floats in the first block you do not always get the same result from operations that should give the same answer. Non-terminating decimals (e.g. 1/3) will always be rounded, unpredictably, by the computer because it doesnâ€™t have infinite memory. The process of rounding means that you need to be very careful comparing floats (more on this later).

title: Python, the Basics
text:
Comparing Variables
For numeric variables comparisons are easy.



Operator
Input
Result




==
10 == 5
False


!=
10 != 5
True


<, <=
10 < 5
False


>, >=
10 > 5
True




The result of any (successful) comparison is a Boolean (True/False). We can save the output of this comparison to a new variable (e.g. z = x > y).
This last example has to do with the way that strings are compared.

title: Python, the Basics
text:
Strings Are Different
But notice:
w, x, y, z = '4a','4a','365','42'
w == x  # True
w != y  # True
x > y   # True
x > z   # True
Why is 4a greater than both 365 and 42?

title: Python, the Basics
text:
Danger, Will Robinson!
Notice the very subtle visual difference between = and ==!
x = 5
y = 10
x = y   # Probably a mistake: setting x to the value of y
x == y  # True, because x and z are now both set to 10
Remember this!

Confusing these two operators is the most common source of mistakes early on when learning to code in Python! One (=) does assignment, the other (==) does comparison.

title: Python, the Basics
text:
Common Mistakes
Hereâ€™s the output from some attempts at comparison:
x, y = '42', 42
x==y   # False
x>y    # An error!
This last line produces:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: '>' not supported between instances of 'str' and 'int'
If we want to compare them then weâ€™ll need to change their type:
x > str(y)   # False
int(x) <= y  # True
x > = str(y) # Also True

A really common mistake is to think that string (str) "42" is the same as the integer (int) 42.
Notice that in the first example we can say that 42 is clearly not the same as â€˜42â€™, but we canâ€™t say whether itâ€™s more or less because thatâ€™s non-sensical in this context. So this is a computer being totally logical but not always sensible.
Also notice the syntax for this: we have str(<something>) and int(<something>) to convert between types. These are functions, which weâ€™ll spend a lot more time on next week!
Why might it be (fractionally) faster to compare integers than strings?

title: Lists
text:
Whatâ€™s in a List?
In the same way that a paper shopping list holds many â€˜typesâ€™ of shopping in one place, a Python list holds many â€˜typesâ€™ of data in one place.
myList = [1, 3, 5, 7]     # homogenous list
myList = [1, "dog", 7.01] # heterogenous list 
myList = []               # empty list
Python lists are always recognisable by their â€œsquare bracketsâ€: [...]

title: Lists
text:
Whatâ€™s in a List? (Part 2)
In fact, when I say lists can hold many types of data, I should have said that they can hold any type of data:
x = 3
y = "Foo"
z = ["A", "list", 42]

a = [x, y, z] # Holds x, y, *and* list z
The output of print(a) is:
[3, 'Foo', ['A', 'list', 42]]

Weâ€™re going to come back to this a lot later, but for now notice that a list can hold lists!

title: Lists
text:
Using List Indexes
geographers = ["Massey", "Harvey", "Rose"]
Lists are â€˜indexedâ€™ numerically from the zero-th element:










geographers [
0
1
2
]





Massey 1
Harvey 2
Rose 3




print(geographers[1]) #Â Harvey
print(geographers[2]) #Â Rose
print(geographers[3]) # Error: List index out of range

And notice this error: Python tells you waht the problem is. The issue is understanding what the message means if you donâ€™t know the vocabulary.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doreen_Massey_(geographer)https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Harveyhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gillian_Rose_(geographer)

title: Lists
text:
Interpolation
We can also use variables as list indexes:
geographers = ["Massey", "Harvey", "Rose"]
i = 0
print(geographers[i]) #Â Massey
Anything that evaluates (i.e.Â resolves) to a number can be used as an index:
i = 1
print(geographers[i+1]) # Rose
print(geographers[ (i-2+1)*2 ]) #Â Massey

title: Lists
text:
Countdown!
We can â€˜countâ€™ backwards from the end of the list using negative numbers:
geographers = ["Massey", "Harvey", "Rose"]
print( geographers[-1] ) # Rose
print( geographers[-2] ) # Harvey

title: Lists
text:
Does Not Compute!
Errors can be scaryâ€¦ but informative!
geographers = ["Massey", "Harvey", "Rose"]
print( geographers[4] )

IndexError: list index out of range

And then try:
print( geographers[1.25] )

TypeError: list indices must be integers or slices, not float

Notice that Python gives us important hints about the source of the problem!

title: Lists
text:
Slicing & Dicing Lists
You can access more than one element at a time using a slice:
geographers = ["Massey", "Harvey", "Rose"]
print( geographers[0:2] ) #Â ['Massey','Harvey']
print( geographers[1:] )  # ['Harvey', 'Rose']
print( geographers[-2:] ) #Â ['Harvey', 'Rose']
The syntax for a slice is: list[ <start_idx>, <end_idx> ], but end_idx is not included in the slice. And notice:
print( geographers[1:2] ) # ['Harvey']
print( geographers[1] )   #   Harvey

Itâ€™s really subtle, but notice that a slice always returns a list, even if itâ€™s just a list containing one thing. So geographers[1]=='Harvey' but geographers[1:2]==['Harvey']. Not the same thing!

title: Lists
text:
Test Yourself
What do you think this will produce?
geographers = ["Massey", "Harvey", "Rose"]
i = 2
print( geographers[ (i-3)**2-4:-1 ] )
See if you can work out in your head before typing it!

title: Lists
text:
Whereâ€™s Wally?
list.index(...) tells you where something can be found in a list:
geographers = ["Massey", "Harvey", "Rose"]
geographers.index("Harvey") #Â 1
geographers.index("Massey") #Â 0
Combining ideas that will become very useful later:
print(geographers[ geographers.index("Massey") ])
What do you think this prints? Why does it work at all?

This last example looks a little strange, but what if I had a separate list with first names, or Wikipedia links, or other information about these geographers? Because list.index(x) returns an integer we can use it as an index for accessing another list.

title: Lists
text:
Whereâ€™s Wally (Part 2)
list.index(...) has one flaw:
geographers = ["Massey", "Harvey", "Rose"]
geographers.index('Batty')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ValueError: 'Batty' is not in list
If â€˜throwing an errorâ€™ is overkill, then hereâ€™s another way:
if 'Batty' in geographers:
    print("Found Mike!")
else:
    print("Not a geographer!")

title: Lists
text:
Sorting
We can sort lists in alpha-numerical order:
geographers = ["Massey", "Harvey", "Rose"]
geographers.sort()
print(geographers) # ['Harvey', 'Massey', 'Rose']
And we can reverse-sort too:
geographers.sort(reverse=True)
print(geographers) # ['Rose', 'Massey', 'Harvey']

title: Lists
text:
Lists are Mutable
Mutable == â€œliable or subject to change or alterationâ€
Letâ€™s replace Rose with Jefferson1 in the list.
geographers = ["Massey", "Harvey", "Rose"]
geographers[2] = "Jefferson"
print(geographers) #Â ['Massey','Harvey','Jefferson']
the-women-cartographers-who-mapped-art-and-science-in-the-20th-century

title: Lists
text:
Adding/Removing Items
When we insert() items into, or pop() items out of, a list we normally need to specify the index.
geographers = ["Massey", "Harvey", "Jefferson"]
geographers.insert(0,"von Humboldt")
print(geographers) 
# ['von Humboldt', 'Massey', 'Harvey', 'Jefferson']
geographers.insert(3,"von Humboldt")
print(geographers) 
# ['von Humboldt', 'Massey', 'Harvey', 'von Humboldt', 'Jefferson']
And in â€˜reverseâ€™:
geographers.pop(3) #Â 'von Humboldt'
print(geographers) 
# ['von Humboldt', 'Massey', 'Harvey', 'Jefferson']

Notice also that insert modifies the list and returns nothing, while pop modifies the list and returns the value that you â€˜poppedâ€™.

title: Lists
text:
Test Yourself
There are two ways to remove David Harvey from the list of geographers without writing this:
geographers = ['von Humboldt', 'Massey', 'Harvey', 'Jefferson']
geographers.pop(2) # Do not use this answer!

You can adapt an example we saw earlier in â€˜Finding Thingsâ€™.
You can use Google to see if there are list operations weâ€™ve not covered.


Hints: remove and del are both options for 2.

title: Lists
text:
Concatenating
We combine lists using addition:
female_geographers = ['Rose','Valentine','Massey','Jefferson']
male_geographers = ['Von Humboldt','Harvey','HÃ¤gerstrand']
all_geographers = female_geographers + male_geographers
print(all_geographers)    # ['Rose', ..., 'HÃ¤gerstrand']
print(all_geographers[0]) # Rose

title: Lists
text:
Appending
Note that this is not the same!
female_geographers = ['Rose','Valentine','Massey','Jefferson']
male_geographers   = ['Von Humboldt','Harvey','HÃ¤gerstrand']
all_geographers = []
all_geographers.append(female_geographers)
 all_geographers.append(male_geographers)
print(all_geographers) # [['Rose',...], [..., 'HÃ¤gerstrand']]
print(all_geographers[0]) # ['Rose', ..., 'Jefferson']
What do you think has happened here?

title: Lists
text:
Test Yourself
male_geographers = ['Von Humboldt','Harvey','HÃ¤gerstrand']
male_geographers.append('Batty')
print(male_geographers)
What do you think this will produce? And why do you think that append appears to do something different in these two examples?

title: Lists
section: How many geographers do I know?
text:
How many geographers do I know?
len(...) gives you the length of â€˜countableâ€™ things:
geographers = ["Massey","Harvey","Rose"]
len(geographers) #Â 3
Butâ€¦
female_geographers = ['Rose','Valentine','Massey','Jefferson']
male_geographers = ['Von Humboldt','Harvey','HÃ¤gerstrand']
all_geographers = []
all_geographers.append(female_geographers)
all_geographers.append(male_geographers)
print( len(all_geographers) ) # 2

title: Lists
text:
Whoâ€™s on the List?
geographers = ["Massey","Harvey","Rose"]
print("Massey" in geographers) # True
print("Batty" in geographers)  # False
Butâ€¦
geographers.index('Batty')
is a ValueError that causes your Python code to fail.

Why might you choose one of these over the other?

title: Lists
text:
Test Yourself
How would you change this code:
geographers = ["Massey","Harvey","Rose"]
print("Massey" in geographers)
print("Batty" in geographers)
So that it prints:
False
True
You will have seen the answer to this in Code Camp, but you can also Google itâ€ !


â€  Iâ€™d suggest looking first at Stack Overflow answers in most cases.

title: Lists
text:
Tuples: Not Actually a List
Because they come up a lot in geo-data, itâ€™s worth knowing about tuples, which are basically immutable lists:
t = (52.124021, -0.0012012)
print(type(t)) # <class 'tuple'>
print(t)       # (52.124021, -0.0012012)
print(t[0])    # 52.124021
But thisâ€¦
t[0] = 25.1203210
will throw an error:

TypeError: â€˜tupleâ€™ object does not support item assignment

title: Data Structures
Data Structures
text:
Implications

So we can mix and match dictionaries and lists in whatever way we need to storeâ€¦ â€˜dataâ€™. The question is then: whatâ€™s the right way to store our data?


Answer: the way that makes the most sense to a human while also being the most robust for coding.

title: Data Structures
text:
But Compareâ€¦
How do these data structures differ?


Option 1
ds1 = [
  ['lat','lon','name','tz'],
  [51.51,0.13,'London',+0],
  [40.71,74.01,'New York',-5],
  [35.69,139.68,'Tokyo',+8]
]

Option 2
ds2 = {
  'lat': [51.51,40.71,35.69],
  'lon': [0.13,74.01,139.68],
  'tz':  [+0,-5,+8],
  'name':['London','New York','Tokyo']
}


To understand why Iâ€™m asking this question, here are two example questions Iâ€™d like you to try to answer:

Whatâ€™s the average latitude of these three cities?
Whatâ€™s the time zone of Tokyo?

title: Data Structures
text:
Thinking it Through
Why does this work for both computers and people?
ds2 = {
  'lat': [51.51,40.71,35.69],
  'lon': [0.13,74.01,139.68],
  'tz':  [+0,-5,+8],
  'name':['London','New York','Tokyo']
}

We are doing away with the idea that the order of columns matters (humans donâ€™t care that a cityâ€™s name is in the first column, and a cityâ€™s latitude in the second). We just want to find the column. But because we have a dictionary-of-lists we can ensure that the row order is preserved. Letâ€™s see this in action.

title: Data Structures
text:
Examples
ds2 = {
  'lat': [51.51,40.71,35.69],
  'lon': [0.13,74.01,139.68],
  'tz':  [+0,-5,+8],
  'name':['London','New York','Tokyo']
}

print(ds2['name'][0]) #Â London
print(ds2['lat'][0])  # 51.51
print(ds2['tz'][0])   # 0
So 0 always returns information about London, and 2 always returns information about Tokyo. But itâ€™s also easy to ask for the latitude (ds2['lat'][0]) or time zone (ds2['tz'][0]) value once you know that 0 is London!

But thereâ€™s another advantage thatâ€™s not quite so obvious: for the computer because everything of type â€˜latâ€™ is a float, everything of type â€˜tzâ€™ is an integer, and everything of type â€˜nameâ€™ is a string, itâ€™s a lot easier to work with each column as data.

title: Data Structures
text:
How is that easier???
Remember that we can use any immutable â€˜thingâ€™ as a key. This meansâ€¦
ds2 = {
  'lat': [51.51,40.71,35.69],
  'lon': [0.13,74.01,139.68],
  'tz':  [+0,-5,+8],
  'name':['London','New York','Tokyo']
}

city_nm = 'Tokyo'
city_idx = ds2['name'].index(city_nm)

print(f"The time zone of {city_nm} is {ds2['tz'][city_idx]}")
We can re-write this into a single line as:
city_nm = 'New York'
print(f"The time zone of {city_nm} is {ds2['tz'][ ds2['name'].index(city_nm)]}")

This achieves several useful things:

It is fast: faster than iterating over a list-of-lists or dictionary-of-dictionaries. In other words, there is no iteration at all!
All data in a list is of the same type so we can easily add checks to make sure that itâ€™s valid.
We can also easily calculate an average/max/min/median and so on (as weâ€™ll see later) without even having to look at any other columns!
We can add more columns instantly and the process of finding something is just as fast as it is now. And adding more rows doesnâ€™t make it much slower either!

Also, notice how in these two examples we donâ€™t try to write the second example in one go: first, we work it out as a set of steps: how do we figure out what â€˜rowâ€™ (position in the list) Tokyo is in? Now that weâ€™ve got that, how do we retrieve the time zone value for Tokyo? We know that code works, now letâ€™s do variable substitution, as we would if we were doing maths: we can replace the city_idx in the time zone lookup with ds2['name'].index('Tokyo').

title: Getting to Grips with Git
text:
How It Works
The natural way normal people think about managing versions of a document is to save a copy with a new name that somehow shows which version is most recent.
The natural way developers used to think about managing versions of a document is to have a master copy somewhere. Everyone asks the server for the master copy, makes some changes, and then checks those changes back in.
This is not how Git works.

The way normal people approach this problem assumes that, usually, only one or two people are making changes. But how do you coordinate with 20 other people to find out who has the most recent copy then collect all 21 peopleâ€™s changes?
The way developers used to approach this problem assumes that someone is in final charge. That a company or organisation runs a server which will decide whose changes are allowed, and whose are not.

title: Getting to Grips with Git
text:
How Git Works
Git is distributed, meaning that every computer where git is installed has its own master copy.
So every computer has a full history of any git project (aka. repository or â€˜repoâ€™). Indeed, you donâ€™t have to synchronise your repo with any other computer or server at all! 1

In order to make this useful, you need ways to synchronise changes between computers that all think theyâ€™re right.

Iâ€™d suggest that this is leaving the benefit of free backups on the table for no good reason!

title: Getting to Grips with Git
text:
GitHub
GitHub is nothing special to Git, just another Git server with which to negotiate changes. Do not think of GitHub as the â€˜masterâ€™ copy. There isnâ€™t one.
There are, however, upstream and remote repositories.

An â€˜upstreamâ€™ repository is where thereâ€™s a â€˜gatekeeperâ€™: e.g.Â the people who run PySAL have a repo that is considered the â€˜gatekeeperâ€™ for PySAL.
A remote repository is any repository with which your copy synchronises. So the remote repository can be â€˜upstreamâ€™ or it can just be another computer you run, or you GitHub account.

title: Getting to Grips with Git
text:
A Dropbox Analogy

Think of JupyterLab as being like Word or Excel: an application that allows you to read/write/edit notebook files.
Think of GitHub as being like Dropbox: a place somewhere in the cloud that files on your home machine can be backed up.

But Dropbox doesnâ€™t have the .gitignore file!

GitHub offers a lot of â€˜value addedâ€™ features (like simple text editing) on top of the basic service of â€˜storing filesâ€™.

title: Getting to Grips with Git
text:
Getting Started



Term
Means




Repository (Repo)
A project or achive stored in Git.


init
To create a new repo on your computer.


clone
To make a full copy of a repo somewhere else.



This creates a local repo that is unsynchronised with anything else:
mkdir test
cd test
git init
Whereas this creates a local clone that is fully synchronised with GitHub:
cd .. #Â To move out of 'test'
git clone https://github.com/jreades/fsds.git

title: Getting to Grips with Git
text:
Working on a File



Term
Means




add
Add a file to a repo.


mv
Move/Rename a file in a repo.


rm
Remove a file from a repo.



For example:
cd test # Back into the new Repo
touch README.md # Create empty file called README.md
git add README.md # Add it to the repository
git mv README.md fileA.md # Rename it (move it)
git rm fileA.md # Remove it... which is an Error!
This produces:
error: the following file has changes staged in the index:
    fileA.md
(use --cached to keep the file, or -f to force removal)

This is telling you that you can force remove (git rm -f fileA.md) if you really want, but youâ€™d probably be better off commiting the changes that have been â€˜stagedâ€™â€¦ more on this in a second!
Also: no one else knows about these changes yet!

title: Getting to Grips with Git
text:
Looking at the History



Term
Means




diff
Show changes between commits.


status
Show status of files in repo.


log
Show history of commits.



For example:
cd ../test/ # In case you weren't already there
git status  # What's the status
This produces:
On branch master

No commits yet

Changes to be committed:
  (use "git rm --cached <file>..." to unstage)
    new file:   fileA.md

So again, git is giving us hints as to the options: â€˜changes to be committedâ€™ vs.Â â€˜unstageâ€™ the changes. We can also see what files are to be committed (i.e.Â have changed).

title: Getting to Grips with Git
section: Working on a Project or File
text:
Working on a Project or File



Term
Means




commit
To record changes to the repo.


branch
Create or delete branches.


checkout
Jump to a different branch.



For example:
git commit -m "Added and then renamed the README."
git status
You should see:
[master (root-commit) e7a0b25] Added and then renamed the README Markdown file.
 1 file changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
 create mode 100644 fileA.md
# ... and then this:
On branch master
nothing to commit, working tree clean
Make a note of the number after â€˜root-commitâ€™!

title: Getting to Grips with Git
text:
Recovery
git rm fileA.md
git status
git commit -m "Removed file."
ls 
git checkout <number you wrote down earlier>
ls 

So every operation on a file is recorded in the repository: adding, renaming, deleting, and so on. And we can roll back any change at any time. For plain-text files (such as Markdown, Python and R scripts) these changes are recorded at the level of each line of code: so you can jump around through your entire history of a project and trace exactly when and what changes you (or anyone else) made.

title: Getting to Grips with Git
text: A Rock-Climbing Analogy

title: Getting to Grips with Git
text:
Collaborating on a Project



Term
Means




pull
To request changes on a repo from another computer.


push
To send changes on a repo to another computer.



For example:
git push

title: Getting to Grips with Git
text:
A Note on Workflow
So your workflow should be:

Save edits to Jupyter notebook.
Run git add <filename.ipynb> to record changes to the notebook (obviously replace <filename.ipynb> completely with the notebook filename.
Run git commit -m "Adding notes based on lecture" (or whatever message is appropriate: -m means â€˜messageâ€™).
Then run git push to push the changes to GitHub.

If any of those commands indicate that there are no changes being recorded/pushed then it might be that youâ€™re not editing the file that you think you are (this happens to me!).
On the GitHub web site you may need to force reload the view of the repository: Shift + Reload button usually does it in most browsers. You may also need to wait 5 to 10 seconds for the changes to become â€˜visibleâ€™ before reloading. Itâ€™s not quite instantaeous.

text:
This is not easy1

title: Packages
text:
Popular Packages



Package
Does




os
Operating System stuff (paths, processes, etc.)


csv
Reading and Writing CSV files.


math
Maths constants and functions.


statistics
Simple statistical tests & measures.


urllib
URL Reading (e.g.Â web pages).


numpy
Numerical Python (scientific computing).


scipy
Scientific Python (more scientific computing)


sklearn
Machine learning, clustering, etc.

title: Packages
text:
Importing a Package
If a package is installed, then itâ€™s as simple as:
import <packagename>
You normally do this at the start of a program so that itâ€™s easy to see what the program requires to run:
import math
print(math.pi) # Prints 3.141592653589793

title: Packages
text:
What Can a Package Do?
There are many ways to find this out:

Read the documentation
Search Google, and
Search StackOverflow

Thereâ€™s even a web site python.readthedocs.io.
But we can also ask the package:
import math
dir(math)
# ['__doc__', '__file__', '__name__', '__package__', ..., 
# 'log', 'log10', 'log1p', 'modf', 'pi', ...]
help(math.log10)

So, remember what I said in the talk about functions: that the numbers and total variables in the function arenâ€™t the same as the ones outside the function? I said the answer had to do with something called the namespace. Here is the math namespace.

title: Packages
text:
Soâ€¦

dir(<package name>) lists all â€˜thingsâ€™ that <package> contains.
By convention, things that start with __ are â€˜privateâ€™ (you shouldnâ€™t change them) and things that start and end with __ are metadata (e.g.Â __version__).
Everything else you can interrogate with help(<package name>.<thing in package>).

With help(math.log10) you get an answer like this:
Help on built-in function log10 in module math:

log10(x, /)
    Return the base 10 logarithm of x.
With help(math.pi) you get an answer Help on float objectâ€¦

This tells you that pi is a float, it doesnâ€™t tell you what Pi is (an irrational number). So hereâ€™s another case where the computer gives you a technically correct but not always helpful answer. In the context of the math package, Pi is a float constant.

title: Packages
text:
Why Namespaces Matter
Consider this:
import math
pi = 4
print(math.pi)
print(pi)
So math.pi and pi are not the same variable!

The latter is implicitly main.pi but Python doesnâ€™t have a â€˜mainâ€™ programme namespace. Everything is â€˜mainâ€™ unless you put it in a package.

title: Packages
text:
More Laziness: Aliases
Programmers hate typing more than they have to:
import math
r = 5
area = math.pi * r**2
ln = math.log(area)
print(ln)
So we can use an alias instead:
import math as m
r = 5
area = m.pi * r**2
ln = m.log(area)
print(ln)
You will see this used a lot with more complex libraries like Pandas (pd), Geopandas (gpd), and PySAL (ps).

title: Packages
text:
Importing Part of a Package
Sometimes even that is too much typingâ€¦ or sometimes we only really want one or two things from a much larger package. In that case we can select these specifically:
from math import pi, log10
print(pi)
help(log10)
This import pi and log10 from math into the â€˜mainâ€™ namespace.

title: Packages
text:
Gotcha!
Notice the subtle differences here:


Approach 1
pi = 3.1415
print(pi)      # 3.1415

import math as m
print(m.pi)    # 3.141592...
print(pi)      # 3.1415
print(math.pi) #Â Error!

Approach 2
pi = 3.1415
print(pi) # 3.1415

from math import pi
print(pi)      # 3.141592...
print(m.pi)    # Error!
print(math.pi) # Error!

title: Object-Oriented Design
text: Tree of Life

title: Object-Oriented Design
text:
Tree of Vehicles
Most people would call this a class hierarchy or diagram.

There is no natural order here: where do e-bikes, unicycles, and rickshaws go?

Indeed, we could map out vehicles based on the number of axles, their source of power, their driver positioning, etc., etc. The point here is that the designer must make choices that are influenced by (and will influence) the design of the application for which this class hierarchy is buing developed. An automobile manufacturer might make different choices from a government trying to implement a tax policy.

title: Object-Oriented Design
text:
Classes vs Packages

Functionally, a class and a package are indistinguishable, but a class produces objects that use methods and instance or class variables, whereas a package is a group of functions and constants that may, or may not, include classes.

Ugh, now try to keep this straight in your head.

title: Object-Oriented Design
text:
Key Takeaways

Youâ€™ve been using Classes and Methods since you started.
You can â€˜package upâ€™ useful code into functions, and useful functions into packages.
Together, packages and classes will turbo-charge your programming skills.
You can stand on the shoulders of giants!

title: Logic
text:
Do You Want?


Consider the following three things Iâ€™ve said to my toddler:

Do you want to go to the park and have ice cream?
Do you want cereal or toast for breakfast?
Do not touch that again or else!

Unlike my toddler, the computer does listen, but my toddler has more common sense!

title: Logic
Logic
Logic
text:
A Special Case
There is a second set of logical operators that apply in very specific circumstances. These are called â€˜bitwiseâ€™ operators and apply to data specified in bits.



Regular Operator
Bitwise Equivalent




and
&


or
|


not
~



Letâ€™s see (briefly) how these workâ€¦

title: Logic
text:
Working With Bits
x,y = 38,3
print(f"{x:b}") # `:b` means byte-format
print(f"{y:b}")
This gives us that x is '100110' and y is '11', so now:
print(f"{x & y:b}")  # 10
print(f"{x | y:b}")  # 100111
print(f"{x & ~y:b}") # 100100

title: Logic
section: Perhaps Easier to See This Way?
text:
Perhaps Easier to See This Way?



Operator
1
2

4
5
6




x
1
0

0


y

Bitwise operations are very, very fast and so are a good way to, say, find things in large data sets. Youâ€™ve been warned.

They are how pandas and numpy manage indexes and queries against data frames.

title: Logic
text:
Nulls: None vs.Â NaN
Beware of using logic with things that are not what they appear:

None is Pythonâ€™s way of saying that something has no value at all (not 0 or ""â€¦ but None). It is a class.
NaN (Not a Number) is a special numeric data type provided by the numpy package to deal with things like -ve and +ve infinity and similar â€˜issuesâ€™.

np.nan should be used whenever you are dealing with data (e.g. see Pandas!).

title: Logic
text:
None vs.Â NaN
import numpy as np
print(type(np.nan))     # float
print(type(None))       # NoneType
Critically:
print(""==None)         # False
print(None==None)       # True
print(np.nan==None)     # False
print(np.nan==np.nan)   # False!
print(np.nan is np.nan) # True
print(np.isnan(np.nan)) # True

title: Logic
text:
In / Not In
Weâ€™ve touched on these before:
g = ['Harvey','Rose','Batty','Jefferson']

if 'Batty' in g:
  print("In the group!")

if 'Marx' not in g:
  print("Not in the group!")
The set data type also supports in, and not in together with all of the set maths (union, intersect, etc.).

This is a good place for a recap though.

title: File Formats
text:
From Files to Data
In order to read a file you need to know a few things:

What distinguishes one record from another?
What distinguishes one field from another?
What ensures that a field or record is valid?
Does the data set have row or column names? (a.k.a. headers & metadata)
Is the metadata in a separate file or embedded in the file?

title: File Formats
section: Structure of a Tabular Data File
text:
Structure of a Tabular Data File
Row and column names make it a lot easier to find and refer to data (e.g. the â€˜East of England rowâ€™ or the â€˜Total columnâ€™) but they are not data and donâ€™t belong in the data set itself.
Usually, one record (a.k.a. observation) finishes and the next one starts with a â€˜newlineâ€™ (\n) or â€™carriage return (\r) or both (\r\n) but it could be anything (e.g.Â EOR).
Usually, one field (a.k.a. attribute or value) finishes and the next one starts with a comma (,) which gives rise to CSV (Comma-Separate Values), but it could be tabs (\t) or anything else too (; or | or EOF).

How would we choose a good field separator?
Pro tip: if we store column and row names separately from the data then we can access everything easily without having to factor in any â€˜specialâ€™ values!
Noice also the nd here. This is the escape sequence again that you also encountered when dealing with the Shell as well. Remember that \ is necessary if you have a space in your file name or path.

title: File Formats
text:
Most Common Formats









Extension
Field Separator
Record Separator
Python Package




.csv
, but separator can appear in fields enclosed by ".
\n but could be \r or \r\n.
csv


.tsv or .tab
\t and unlikely to appear in fields.
\n but could be \r or \r\n.
csv (!)


.xls or .xlsx
Binary, you need a library to read.
Binary, you need a library to read.
xlrd/xlsxwriter


.sav or .sas
Binary, you need a library to read.
Binary, you need a library to read.
pyreadstat


.json, .geojson
Complex (,, [], {}), but plain text.
Complex (,, [], {}), but plain text
json, geojson


.feather
Binary, you need a library to read.
Binary, you need a library to read.
pyarrow, geofeather


.parquet
Binary, you need a library to read.
Binary, you need a library to read.
pyarrow




One of the reasons we like CSV and TSV files is that they can be opened and interacted with using the Command Line (as well as Excel/Numbers/etc.) directly. As soon as you get into binary file formats you either need the original tool (and then export) or you need a tool that can read those formats. So the complexity level rises very quickly.
Of course, sometimes you can gain (e.g.Â SPSS or SAS) in terms of obtaining information about variable types, levels, etc. but usually you use these when thatâ€™s all thatâ€™s available or when you want to write a file for others to use.
The two formats at the bottom of the table are there because they are useful: the feather format was designed for fast reads and for data interachange with R, while Parquet is a highly-compressed, column-oriented storage format for large data. So for modest-sized data sets (a few hundred MB), or situations where you are working across R and Python, then Feather cannot be beat. For â€˜big dataâ€™ where you need access to parts of the data set and want to do lazy loading, then parquet is the winner.

title: File Formats
text:
â€˜Mappingâ€™ Data Types
You will often see the term â€˜mappingâ€™ used in connection to data that is not spatial, what do they mean? A map is the term used in some programming languages for a dict! So itâ€™s about key : value pairs again.
Hereâ€™s a mapping







Input (e.g.Â Excel)
Output (e.g.Â Python)




NULL, N/A, â€œâ€
None or np.nan


0..n
int


0.00â€¦n
float


True/False, Y/N, 1/0
bool


R, G, B (etc.)
int or str (technically a set, but hard to use with data sets)


â€˜Jon Readesâ€™, â€˜Huanfa Chenâ€™, etc.
str


â€˜3-FEB-2020â€™, â€˜10/25/20â€™, etc.
datetime module (date, datetime or time)




These would be a mapping of variables between two formats. We talk of mapping any time we are taking inputs from one data set/format/data structure as a lookup for use with another data set/format/data structure.
Have a think about how you can use an int to represent nominal data. There are two ways: one of which will be familiar to students who have taken a stats class (with regression) and one of which is more intuitive to â€˜normalâ€™ usersâ€¦

title: File Formats
text:
Testing a Mapping
Working out an appropriate mapping (representation of the data) is hugely time-consuming.

Itâ€™s commonly held that 80% of data science is data cleaning.

The Unix utilities (grep, awk, tail, head) can be very useful for quickly exploring the data in order to develop a basic understanding of the data and to catch obvious errors.
You should never assume that the data matches the spec.

title: File Formats
text:
Label These



Metadata is relevant to our understanding of the data and so is important, but itâ€™s not relevant to treating the data as data so we need to be able to skip it.
Column names are going to be how we access a given attribute for each observation.
Row names are not normally data themselves, but are basically labels or identifiers for observations. Another term for this would be the data index.
If we store row and column names/indices separately from the data then we donâ€™t have to treat them as â€˜specialâ€™ or factor them into, for example, the calculation of summary stats.
Also have to consider trade-offs around mapping the full column names on to something a little faster and easier to type!

title: File Formats
text:
Things That Can Go Wrongâ€¦
A selection of real issues Iâ€™ve seen in my life:

Truncation: server ran out of diskspace or memory, or a file transfer was interrupted.
Translation: headers donâ€™t line up with data.
Swapping: column order differs from spec.
Incompleteness: range of real values differs from spec.
Corruption: field delimitters included in field values.
Errors: data entry errors resulted in incorrect values or the spec is downright wrong.
Irrelevance: fields that simply arenâ€™t relevant to your analysis.

These will generally require you to engage with columns and rows (via sampling) on an individual level.

title: File Formats
text:
Arrow and Parquet

Arrow is an in-memory columnar format for data. Data is stored in a structured way in RAM making it blazingly fast for operations.
Parquet is a highly-compressed columnar file format for data. Data is stored in a structured way on your hard drive.
Feather is a raw storage format for Arrow.

TL;DR: for most applications Parquet will give nice, small files on disk and the benefits of columnar file storage; for computationally intensive applications where disk space and interoperability with other systems isnâ€™t an issue then Feather might work.

title: File Formats
text:
What About the Duck?





Serverless SQL queries against Parquet files
Queries returned as Pandas data frames
Select and filter before loading
Fast conversion between CSV and Parquet via Arrow

title: File Formats
text:
For (Later) Reference
# Notice the engine and dtype_backend options
df = pandas.read_csv(fname, engine='pyarrow', 
                dtype_backend='pyarrow')

# And for parquet files
df = pandas.read_parquet(fname, columns=[...])

# And for DuckDB we can actually joing two
# files before they even get to Python!
q = f'''
  SELECT * FROM 
    read_parquet('epc-ppd-2022-*.parquet') as ppd, 
    read_parquet('epc-ldd-2022-*.parquet') as ldd,
  WHERE ppd.uid=ldd.uid
'''
df = duckdb.query(q).df()
P.S. Thereâ€™s also a command-line tool for DuckDB so you donâ€™t even need Python.

title: Computational Mapping
text:
Two Cultures


Purely Computational
Both analysis and visualisation are accomplished via code:

Fully replicable (including random samples).
Fully documented (to extent commented by dev).
Fully portable (assuming no platform-specific code).


Mostly Computational
Only the analysis is accomplished via code, visualisation is via a GIS:

Wider variety of output formats (e.g.Â Atlases, 3D/web).
Better support for â€˜finishing touchesâ€™ (e.g.Â scalebars, north arrows, rule-based labels, etc.).
Better-quality output for less effort (e.g.Â Model Builder + QGIS styles).



Worth reflecting on pros and cons of these: when does one offer benefits over the other?

title: Computational Mapping
text:
The Challenge
The hardest part of purely computational approaches is the need to anticipate how maps will look according to variations in:

The density and type of data
The context of the data
The different scales involved
The number of maps involved
The need to annotate and label elements

Ultimately, the complexity of the choices here may require the use of a scriptable GIS over ggplot or matplotlib.

Donâ€™t forget that both QGIS and Arc offer a â€˜Model Builderâ€™ that is basically â€˜visual programmingâ€™.

title: Computational Mapping
text: Think it Through!

title: Computational Mapping
text:
A Deceptively Simple Problem

We want to show data on a map in a way that is both accurate and informative.

Why might this not be possible?

title: Computational Mapping
text:
Classification
Trade-offs:

The greater the accuracy of a choropleth or other class-based map, the less itâ€™s possible generalise from it.
There is no â€˜rightâ€™ way to group data into an arbitrary number of discrete classes (a.k.a. to generalise).

Humans can only take in so much data at once. Your choice of colour scheme, breaks, and classification can profoundly affect how people see the world.

title: Computational Mapping
text: Six Views of Employment

title: Computational Mapping
text: Six Views of Employment

title: Computational Mapping
text: Six Views of Employment

title: Computational Mapping
text:
Consider
We want to:

Group features with similar values together.
Show these in a way that doesnâ€™t mislead the viewer.

But we have the following problems:

Too many classes confuse the viewer.
Too few classes hides structure/pattern.

title: Computational Mapping
text:
Choices, Choices
At the very least we have the following options:

Assign classes manually.
Split range evenly (i.e.Â equal intervals).
Split data evenly (i.e.Â quantiles).
Split data according to distribution (i.e.Â SD).
Split data so that members of each group are more similar to each other than to members of another group (i.e.Â natural breaks/Jencks).

title: Computational Mapping
text:
Look at the Data!
Different colour and break schemes not only give us different views of the data, they give us different understandings of the data! Each scheme changes how the data looks and, consequently, how we perceive the distribution.

text: Takeaway: Maps have a â€˜Rhetoricâ€™

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Epicyclic Feedback
Peng and Matsui, The Art of Data Science, p.8










Set Expectations
Collect Information
Revise Expectations




Question
Question is of interest to audience
Literature search/experts
Sharpen question


EDA
Data are appropriate for question
Make exploratory plots
Refine question or collect more data


Modelling
Primary model answers question
Fit secondary models / analysis
Revise model to include more predictors


Interpretation
Interpretation provides specific and meaningful answer
Interpret analyses with focus on effect and uncertainty
Revise EDA and/or models to provide more specific answers


Communication
Process & results are complete and meaningful
Seek feedback
Revises anlyses or approach to presentation

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Approaching EDA
Thereâ€™s no hard and fast way of doing EDA, but as a general rule youâ€™re looking to:

Clean
Canonicalise
Clean More
Visualise & Describe
Review
Clean Some More
â€¦

The â€˜jokeâ€™ is that 80% of Data Science is data cleaning.

Cleaning Part 1: testing validity of records (possibly while tracking rejected records for subsequent analysis)
Canonicalisation: controling for variation (e.g.Â typos, capitalisation, formatting, leading/trailing whitespace, different types of NULL values, etc.) and in a spatial context deal with projection and geo-data issues.
Cleaning Part 2: further testing of records (e.g.Â deciding what to do with NaNs, missing values, outside of study area, etc.)
Visualise & Describe: covered in QM but weâ€™ll take a high-level look at this.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
A Related Take
EDAâ€”Donâ€™t ask how, ask what:

Descriptive Statistics: get a high-level understanding of your dataset.
Missing values: come to terms with how bad your dataset is.
Distributions and Outliers: and why countries that insist on using different units make our jobs so much harder.
Correlations: and why sometimes even the most obvious patterns still require some investigating.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Another Take
Hereâ€™s another view of how to do EDA:

Preview data randomly and substantially
Check totals such as number of entries and column types
Check nulls such as at row and column levels
Check duplicates: do IDs recurr, did the servers fail
Plot distribution of numeric data (univariate and pairwise joint distribution)
Plot count distribution of categorical data
Analyse time series of numeric data by daily, monthly and yearly frequencies

Start with a Chart
The problem of relying on statistics alone was amply illustrated by Anscombeâ€™s Quartet (1973)â€¦

We are not very good at looking at spreadsheets.
We are very good at spotting patterns visually.

Sometimes, we are too good; thatâ€™s where the stats comes in. Think of it as the â€˜tiger in the jungleâ€™ problem..

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
section: But What do They Look Like?
text: But What do They Look Like?

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
The Tiger that Isnâ€™t

I would argue that the basic purpose of charts and of statistics as a whole is to help us untangle signal from noise. We are â€˜programmedâ€™ to see signals, so we need to set the standard for â€˜itâ€™s a tiger!â€™ quite high in research & in policy-making.


Or, as Albert Einstein reportedly said: â€œIf I canâ€™t picture it, I canâ€™t understand it.â€

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Think it Through
You can make a lot of progress in your research without any advanced statistics!

A â€˜pictureâ€™ isnâ€™t just worth 1,000 words, it could be a whole dissertation!
The right chart makes your case eloquently and succinctly.

Always ask yourself:

What am I trying to say?
How can I say it most effectively?
Is there anything Iâ€™m overlooking in the data?

A good chart is a good way to start!

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
What Makes a Good Plot?
A good chart or table:

Serves a purpose â€” it is clear how it advances the argument in a way that could not be done in the text alone.
Contains only what is relevant â€” zeroes in on what the reader needs and is not needlessly cluttered.
Uses precision that is meaningful â€” doesnâ€™t clutter the chart with needless numbers.


Far too many charts or tables could be easily written up in a single sentence.
Far too many charts or tables contain redundancy, clutter, and â€˜flairâ€™.
Donâ€™t report average height of your class to sub-millimeter level accuracy, or lat/long to sub-atomic scale.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
The Purpose of a Chart
The purpose of a graph is to show that there are relationships within the data set that are not trivial/expected.
Choose the chart to highlight relationships, or the lack thereof:

Think of a chart or table as part of your â€˜argumentâ€™ â€“ if you canâ€™t tell me how a figure advances your argument (or if your explanation is more concise than the figure) then you probably donâ€™t need it.
Identify & prioritise the relationships in the data.
Choose a chart type/chart symbology that gives emphasis to the most important relationships.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Not Everyone Likes Tables

Getting information from a table is like extracting sunlight from a cucumber. Arthur & Henry Fahrquhar 1891)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Real Numbers
Consider the difference in emphasis between:

11316149
11,316,149
11.3 million
11 x 10\(^{6}\)
22%
22.2559%

Always keep in mind the purpose of the number.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
section: Thereâ€™s Still a Role for Tables
text:
Thereâ€™s Still a Role for Tables
Why a table is sometimes better than a chart:

You need to present data values with greater detail
You need to enable readers to draw comparisons between data values
You need to present the same data in multiple ways (e.g. raw number and percentage)
You want to show many dimensions for a small number of observations


e.g. percentage of people falling into each ethnic or income category for a small number of wards or boroughs.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Design for Tables
Principles:

Reduce the number of lines to a minimum (and you should almost never need vertical lines).
Use â€˜white-spaceâ€™ to create visual space between groups of unrelated (or less related) elements.
Remove redundancy (if you find yourself typing â€˜millionsâ€™ or â€˜GBPâ€™ or â€˜Maleâ€™ repeatedly then youâ€™ve got redundancy).
Ensure that meta-data is clearly separate from, but attached to, the graph (i.e. source, title, etc.).

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Getting Started
You can follow along by loading the Inside Airbnb sample:
import pandas as pd
import geopandas as gpd
url='https://bit.ly/3I0XDrq'
df = pd.read_csv(url)
df.set_index('id', inplace=True)
df['price'] = df.price.str.replace('$','',regex=False).astype('float')
gdf = gpd.GeoDataFrame(df, 
            geometry=gpd.points_from_xy(
                        df['longitude'], 
                        df['latitude'], 
                        crs='epsg:4326'
            )
      )
gdf.to_file('Airbnb_Sample.gpkg', driver='GPKG')

Note that this (re)loads the sampled Airbnb data from GitHub every time you run it. For a large data set on someone elseâ€™e server you might want to save and (re)load it locally. A simple helper function would then just check if the file already existed locally before trying to download the file again: that would allow you to work while offline and speed up your code substantially too!

title: Exploratory Data Analysis

What Can We Do? (Series)
This is by no means all that we can doâ€¦

print(f"Standard dev is {gdf.price.std():.2f}")

# ...
print(df.corr())
print(df.describe())

Summarise




Notice how we have the same functionality, but it operates at the level of the data set itself now. We gain a few new functions as well that relate to interactions between columns (a.k.a. data series).

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
Measures
So pandas provides functions for commonly-used measures:
print(f"{df.price.mean():.2f}")
print(f"{df.price.median():.2f}")
print(f"{df.price.quantile(0.25):.2f}")
Output:
118.4542
80.50
40.75

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
More Complex Measures
But Pandas also makes it easy to derive new variablesâ€¦ Hereâ€™s the z-score:
\[ z = \frac{x - \bar{x}}{s}\]
df['zscore'] = (df.price - df.price.mean())/df.price.std()
df.plot.box(column='zscore')

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
And Even More Complex
And hereâ€™s the Interquartile Range Standardised score:
\[ x_{iqrs} = \frac{x - \widetilde{x}}{Q_{75} - Q_{25}} \]
df['iqr_std'] = (df.price - df.price.median())/ \
      (df.price.quantile(q=0.75)-df.price.quantile(q=0.25))
df.plot.box(column='iqr_std')

title: Exploratory Data Analysis
text:
The Plot Thickens
Weâ€™ll get to more complex plotting over the course of the term, but hereâ€™s a good start for exploring the data! All plotting depends on matplotlib which is the ogre in the attic to Râ€™s ggplot.
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
Get used to this import as it will allow you to save and manipulate the figures created in Python. It is not the most intuitive approach (unless youâ€™ve used MATLAB before) but it does work.

Itâ€™s not just about mixing code and comment, we also want:

To separate content from presentation
To define mappings between presentation styles

LaTeX







Intended for type-setting of scientific documents, but has been used for slides, posters, CVs, etc. It is not a word processor, itâ€™s more like a compiler.
This format is based on Edward Tufteâ€™s VSQD and can be found on GitHub.
